sub_topic: Determining the rank of a matrix
message_1:
Consider the matrix A = 
\begin{pmatrix} 
1 & 2 & 3 \\
4 & 5 & 6 \\
7 & 8 & 9
\end{pmatrix}

Determine the rank of the matrix A using elementary row operations.
message_2:
To determine the rank of the matrix A, we will perform elementary row operations to transform it into its row-echelon form.

Matrix A:
\begin{pmatrix} 
1 & 2 & 3 \\
4 & 5 & 6 \\
7 & 8 & 9
\end{pmatrix}

Step 1: Subtract 4 times the first row from the second row, and subtract 7 times the first row from the third row.

\begin{pmatrix} 
1 & 2 & 3 \\
0 & -3 & -6 \\
0 & -6 & -12
\end{pmatrix}

Step 2: Divide the second row by -3.

\begin{pmatrix} 
1 & 2 & 3 \\
0 & 1 & 2 \\
0 & -6 & -12
\end{pmatrix}

Step 3: Add 6 times the second row to the third row.

\begin{pmatrix} 
1 & 2 & 3 \\
0 & 1 & 2 \\
0 & 0 & 0
\end{pmatrix}

Now, the matrix is in row-echelon form. The rank of a matrix is the number of non-zero rows in its row-echelon form. In this case, there are 2 non-zero rows.

Therefore, the rank of matrix A is 2.
